caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC v EDWARD ACQUAYE @NANA ABOR YAMOAH II EX-PARTE
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana, in Republic v Edward Acquaye @ Nana Abor Yamoah II, addressed a contempt case arising from a chieftaincy dispute. The High Court had found Acquaye guilty of contempt for acting as chief of Gomoa Fetteh contrary to a 2001 order to maintain the status quo. The Court of Appeal reversed this, interpreting 'status quo' as preserving the state of affairs where Acquaye had been installed and gazetted as chief after the destoolment of his predecessor. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appealâ€™s decision, emphasizing that the superior courts lack jurisdiction over chieftaincy matters as courts of first instance and that the appeal was improperly framed. The Court rejected the appellants' attempt to broaden the scope of the appeal, reaffirming that contempt must be proven beyond reasonable doubt and that the original chieftaincy dispute should be resolved by the appropriate traditional council.
citations: Republic vrs. SITO 1 Ex-parte Fordjour [2001-2002] SCGLR 322
In Re: Effiduase Stool Affairs (No.2) [1998-99] SCGLR 639
Okofoh Estates Limited vrs Modern Signs {1996-97 SCGLR.227}
rationaleHighlights: The term 'status quo' was interpreted as the existing state of affairs where Nana Abor Yamoah II had been installed and gazetted as chief.
Superior courts lack jurisdiction to hear chieftaincy matters as courts of first instance.
Contempt, being quasi-criminal, must be proven beyond reasonable doubt.
The Supreme Court refused to expand its jurisdiction to address underlying chieftaincy issues not properly before it.
The appeal was dismissed for misdirection and failure to recognize jurisdictional limits.
The Court emphasized that the proper forum for resolving the chieftaincy dispute remains the Judicial Committee of the Traditional Council.
The High Court's contempt finding was overturned due to incorrect interpretation of the order.
The Court criticized the litigants and counsel for pursuing a contempt route instead of resolving the core chieftaincy matter.
